CARDINAL . The former Code of Criminal Procedure ( in force until DATE ) , applicable at the material time , stipulated the competence of the domestic courts . Section CARDINAL provided that GPE ( as the courts of first instance ) examined criminal cases not falling within the competence of ORG . According to section CARDINAL ORG examined all cases involving very serious crimes and some other categories of legally complex cases , in addition to their inherent competence as courts of appeal . Aggravated burglaries involving large amounts ( section CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL of LAW ) were very serious crimes and thus had to be examined by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ( effective as of DATE ) amendments to LAW were adopted with a view to reducing the backlog of cases before certain GPE Courts and ORG . They were also aimed at ensuring an even distribution of cases among domestic courts . The competence of ORG was established to hear cases involving specific crimes prescribed by LAW as courts of first instance . It no longer included any type of burglaries . Thus starting from DATE cases involving burglaries had to be examined by GPE . Yet , according to the transitional provision cases where the accused had already been committed for trial before DATE were to be examined by the court that initially received the case .

CARDINAL . On DATE ( effective as of DATE ) another set of amendments to LAW was adopted with regard to the detention of minors . According to transitional provision no . CARDINAL in cases where a minor was kept in detention , the trial had not yet commenced and if a case had been sent for adjudicating to ORG but after DATE it fell to be examined by GPE , the latter could examine the case if ORG decided about the transfer .

CARDINAL . According to section CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure a civil claim could be submitted by an individual who had suffered damage as a result of crime . It could be brought against the accused or the person who was materially liable for the acts of the accused . By virtue of section CARDINAL the investigator or the public prosecutor determined who bore the liability for a civil claim . If it was not the accused , the civil respondent , for example parents of the accused , had to be joined in the proceedings . Attachment of property could be imposed on the assets of the accused or of a person who was materially liable for the acts of the accused in order to secure a civil claim ( section CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . In relation to the complaint procedure , section QUANTITY gave a victim of a crime and a civil party the right to complain about the actions of the investigator or the public prosecutor . Further sections of LAW specified the procedure for complaints before and against the actions of a public prosecutor . The prosecutor had to decide upon a complaint within DATE following its receipt and notify the petitioner . The decision could be appealed against to a higher - ranking public prosecutor .

CARDINAL . With regard to the trial at the first - instance court , LAW , paragraph CARDINAL set a time - limit for committing the accused for trial . The decision had to be adopted within DATE of the date when the case was received at the court . Pursuant to section CARDINAL , adjudication of a case in a hearing had to be commenced within DATE ( in exceptional cases within DATE ) of the date when the case was received at the court . A legal representative of a minor was required to take part in the proceedings until the minor reached the age of majority ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Finally , section CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL of LAW , concerning decisions of an appellate court , stipulated that a judgment or its operative part ( rezolutīvā daļa ) had to be pronounced . If only the operative part was pronounced , this had to be done in writing . The reasoned judgment had to be drawn up within DATE .
